instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS: What is PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS? PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS is 20v in from the USB-C charger on USB-C powered Macbook Pros..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> turn on with battery
threads.message:
so I have this board which can turn on with battery, but if i plug charger, it doesnt show any amperage or voltage, if I unplug the battery, i get only 5v but its not turning on, and I see that I don't have ppbus without battery..but its not shorted.
 I have tried replacing both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip with the chicken wing chip I bought from ali..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> turn on with battery
threads.message:
Did you solder the same termination code?
C00 and B03 are not compatible.

Post diode mode to ground on all LDO outputs of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
Do you get these LDO voltages?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> turn on with battery
threads.message:
same termination code
I got 3,3v on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>
1.79v on pin 2, on bothof these chip

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> turn on with battery
threads.message:
I said all, what about 1V1 LDO?
Also compare diode mode reading between both chips.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> turn on with battery
threads.message:
diode mode of pp3v3, 1v8, and 1v1 for both chip is same, at 4.59
but I don't have voltage on <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> turn on with battery
threads.message:
Check LDO voltages when you connect charger on corresponding port.

Diode mode, always check with red probe at ground...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> turn on with battery
threads.message:
regardless of whch port, ldo voltage for 3.3 = 3.3, for 1.8v = 1.79v, 1.1v = 0v
diode mode value already with red probe

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> turn on with battery
threads.message:
Really 4.59 in diode mode???

Some notes here...

=<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_UPC_XB</SIGNAL> 358 <CAPACITOR>C3200</CAPACITOR>
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> 485 <CAPACITOR>C3204</CAPACITOR>
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> 464 <CAPACITOR>C3205</CAPACITOR>
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> 498 <CAPACITOR>C3206</CAPACITOR>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> 504 <CAPACITOR>C3208</CAPACITOR>
<SIGNAL>UPC_XB_SS</SIGNAL> 494 <CAPACITOR>C3209</CAPACITOR>
=<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS</SIGNAL> 138 F3010

Todas las tensiones LDO de los chips <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> (1V1, 1V8, 3V3), deben aparecer al tener 5V en el correspondiente puerto USB-C.

You cannot get the same values of course, but in similar range.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> turn on with battery
threads.message:
yeah I mean similar-ish range
for pp3v3 and 1v1 diode mode between two chips is same at 4.59-4.60
for pp1v8 diode mode between two chip is same at 4.40-4,44

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> turn on with battery
threads.message:
4.40 is not the same as 440, do you really get that decimal point in such place???
464 means 0.464 diode mode in my notes...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> turn on with battery
threads.message:
sorry2, I mean 0.460 = 460, not decimal
so it is 0.440 = 440

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> turn on with battery
threads.message: If you don't get 1V1 LDO, something goes wrong with corresponding USB-C port; usually <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> internal problem.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> turn on with battery
threads.message: Hmm.. I have replaced both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> again.., but still.no 1v1 ldo, is there no any other cause maybe? Doubt that the problem comes from the chip, if the chip is good should the 1v1 appear simultaneously or only at the good chip?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> turn on with battery
threads.message:
There is a trick to try.
Remove the input MOSFET and make a short input-output; big pads underneath <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR>/200.
Test each channel and check if <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> appears.
